articles.headline: At the Edge of the World, a New Battleground for the U.S. and China
articles.snippet: The Faroe Islands have become perhaps the most unexpected place for the United States and China to tussle over the Chinese tech giant Huawei.
articles.abstract: The Faroe Islands have become perhaps the most unexpected place for the United States and China to tussle over the Chinese tech giant Huawei.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORSHAVN, Faroe Islands — The mere existence of the Faroe Islands is a wonder. Tall peaks of snow-patched volcanic rock jut out from the North Atlantic Ocean. Steep cliffs plunge into the deep waters of narrow fjords.

articles.headline: Facebook Discovers Fakes That Show Evolution of Disinformation
articles.snippet: Researchers said the profiles, linked to the Epoch Media Group, used photos generated by artificial intelligence in a preview of an “eerie, tech-enabled future of disinformation.”
articles.abstract: Researchers said the profiles, linked to the Epoch Media Group, used photos generated by artificial intelligence in a preview of an “eerie, tech-enabled future of disinformation.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook said on Friday that it had removed hundreds of accounts with ties to the Epoch Media Group, parent company of the Falun Gong-related publication and conservative news outlet The Epoch Times.

articles.headline: Evangelical Leaders Close Ranks With Trump After Scathing Editorial
articles.snippet: Christianity Today’s call for President Trump’s removal gave voice to his evangelical critics. But they remain a minority in a political movement that Mr. Trump has reshaped in his own mold.
articles.abstract: Christianity Today’s call for President Trump’s removal gave voice to his evangelical critics. But they remain a minority in a political movement that Mr. Trump has reshaped in his own mold.
articles.lead_paragraph: The publication is small, reaching just a fraction of the evangelical movement.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: ‘How? How? How?’: Victims’ Families Rage as Matt Bevin Defends Pardons
articles.snippet: Prosecutors cried foul. A mother collapsed to the floor. The outgoing Kentucky governor’s clemency decisions have caused widespread outrage.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors cried foul. A mother collapsed to the floor. The outgoing Kentucky governor’s clemency decisions have caused widespread outrage.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFORT, Ky. — The mother was at home preparing cheese sticks and a milkshake when she got the call. On the other line, a prosecutor had surprising news about the man who had been convicted of repeatedly sexually assaulting her child and sentenced last year to 23 years in prison.
articles.byline: By Sarah Mervosh, Campbell Robertson and Mike Baker

articles.headline: Who Gets to Join a Santa Society? Debate Over Inclusion Divides a Bearded Brotherhood
articles.snippet: It used to be easy for the International Brotherhood of Real Bearded Santas to know who could become a member. No more.
articles.abstract: It used to be easy for the International Brotherhood of Real Bearded Santas to know who could become a member. No more.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, there wasn’t much confusion about who could join the International Brotherhood of Real Bearded Santas, the largest membership organization of Santas in the world. It was open only to men with whiskers long enough to be styled like St. Nick’s, which could withstand a firm tug from a formidable toddler.

articles.headline: Mitch McConnell, Master of the Blockade, Plots Impeachment Strategy
articles.snippet: The Senate majority leader has earned the nickname the grim reaper for his iron-fisted grip on the chamber, but an impeachment trial is harder to control.
articles.abstract: The Senate majority leader has earned the nickname the grim reaper for his iron-fisted grip on the chamber, but an impeachment trial is harder to control.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shattering convention, he held open a Supreme Court seat for 11 months. He twice changed Senate rules to create a record-setting assembly line of conservative federal judicial confirmations. He has been ruthless in his control of the Senate floor, denying Republicans and Democrats alike much opportunity to debate legislation.

articles.headline: Empty Hotels and Salmon Stuck in Traffic: Strike Bites French Economy
articles.snippet: Rail and subway strikes are causing lost sales, lost bookings and lost time throughout the country.
articles.abstract: Rail and subway strikes are causing lost sales, lost bookings and lost time throughout the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Glittering with Christmas decorations, Galeries Lafayette, a famed department store in central Paris, typically draws up to 80,000 visitors a day during the holidays.

articles.headline: U.S. Braces for Major North Korean Weapons Test as Trump’s Diplomacy Fizzles
articles.snippet: President Trump’s summits with Kim Jong-un have failed to bring concrete results, and the diplomatic vacuum has given North Korea more time to build its nuclear arsenal.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s summits with Kim Jong-un have failed to bring concrete results, and the diplomatic vacuum has given North Korea more time to build its nuclear arsenal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American military and intelligence officials tracking North Korea’s actions by the hour say they are bracing for an imminent test of an intercontinental ballistic missile capable of reaching American shores, but appear resigned to the fact that President Trump has no good options to stop it.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Edward Wong and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: ‘I’m Kidnapped’: A Father’s Nightmare on the Border
articles.snippet: A father was tortured in front of his 3-year-old son until his wife in New Jersey paid $2,000 to his captors. Chilling audio of the negotiations for his release shows how migrants, turned back by the U.S., are facing new dangers in Mexico.
articles.abstract: A father was tortured in front of his 3-year-old son until his wife in New Jersey paid $2,000 to his captors. Chilling audio of the negotiations for his release shows how migrants, turned back by the U.S., are facing new dangers in Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: REYNOSA, Mexico — He remembers being on his knees, gagged and blinded with duct tape, his hands tied behind his back. One of his captors struck his left thigh with a bat and scraped his neck with an ax, threatening to cut him.

articles.headline: Fear and Loyalty: How Donald Trump Took Over the Republican Party
articles.snippet: The president demands complete fealty, and as the impeachment hearings showed, he has largely attained it. To cross him is to risk losing a future in the Republican Party.
articles.abstract: The president demands complete fealty, and as the impeachment hearings showed, he has largely attained it. To cross him is to risk losing a future in the Republican Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Mich. — By the summer of 2017, Dave Trott, a two-term Republican congressman, was worried enough about President Trump’s erratic behavior and his flailing attempts to repeal the Affordable Care Act that he criticized the president in a closed-door meeting with fellow G.O.P. lawmakers.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: How a Poisoning in Bulgaria Exposed Russian Assassins in Europe
articles.snippet: For years, members of a secret team, Unit 29155, operated without Western security officials having any idea about their activities. But an attack on an arms dealer in Sofia helped blow their cover.
articles.abstract: For years, members of a secret team, Unit 29155, operated without Western security officials having any idea about their activities. But an attack on an arms dealer in Sofia helped blow their cover.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — The Russian assassin used an alias, Sergei Fedotov, and slipped into Bulgaria unnoticed, checking into a hotel in Sofia near the office of a local arms manufacturer who had been selling ammunition to Ukraine.

articles.headline: At Boeing, C.E.O.’s Stumbles Deepen a Crisis
articles.snippet: Dennis Muilenburg’s handling of the 737 Max grounding after two fatal crashes has angered lawmakers, airlines, regulators and victims’ families.
articles.abstract: Dennis Muilenburg’s handling of the 737 Max grounding after two fatal crashes has angered lawmakers, airlines, regulators and victims’ families.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and David Gelles

articles.headline: #MeToo Clashes With ‘Bro Culture’ at Ad Agencies
articles.snippet: Campaigns promoting female empowerment are all the rage. But women in advertising say they still have to navigate “Mad Men” workplaces.
articles.abstract: Campaigns promoting female empowerment are all the rage. But women in advertising say they still have to navigate “Mad Men” workplaces.
articles.lead_paragraph: The empowerment of women was a major theme of Advertising Week, a yearly gathering of roughly 100,000 ad-industry people in New York. The female R&B group TLC kicked off the program with a concert called “Future Is Female,” and there were panel discussions with titles like “Mom Bosses,” “#RewriteHerStory” and “Time’s Up, Pay Up: We Will Not Wait 100 Years.”

articles.headline: Fighting the Good Fight Against Online Child Sexual Abuse
articles.snippet: Several websites popular with sexual predators were thwarted last month after a determined campaign by groups dedicated to eliminating the content. It was a rare victory in an unending war.
articles.abstract: Several websites popular with sexual predators were thwarted last month after a determined campaign by groups dedicated to eliminating the content. It was a rare victory in an unending war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several websites popular with sexual predators were thwarted last month after a determined campaign by groups dedicated to eliminating the content. It was a rare victory in an unending war.

articles.headline: No ‘Magic Bullets’ in the Fight Against Online Abuse, but ‘Spiders’ Help
articles.snippet: Nearly four dozen nonprofits around the world are dedicated to removing photos and videos of child sexual abuse from the internet. It’s a daunting task.
articles.abstract: Nearly four dozen nonprofits around the world are dedicated to removing photos and videos of child sexual abuse from the internet. It’s a daunting task.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sexual predators have grown increasingly adept at using the internet to share and view child sexual abuse photos and videos. Some have computer-programming skills and have deployed sophisticated defenses against efforts to take them down.

articles.headline: How a String of Flukes Helped Pave the Way for Mayor Michael Bloomberg
articles.snippet: He was told he would lose. In any other year, he probably would have. But 2001 was not any other year.
articles.abstract: He was told he would lose. In any other year, he probably would have. But 2001 was not any other year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg was not entirely picky.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: It Seemed Like a Popular Chat App. It’s Secretly a Spy Tool.
articles.snippet: ToTok, an Emirati messaging app that has been downloaded to millions of phones, is the latest escalation of a digital arms race.
articles.abstract: ToTok, an Emirati messaging app that has been downloaded to millions of phones, is the latest escalation of a digital arms race.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is billed as an easy and secure way to chat by video or text message with friends and family, even in a country that has restricted popular messaging services like WhatsApp and Skype.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Nicole Perlroth and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: A Jungle Airstrip Stirs Suspicions About China’s Plans for Cambodia
articles.snippet: The Chinese military’s “string of pearls” strategy depends on far-flung regional outposts. Some think Cambodia is becoming one.
articles.abstract: The Chinese military’s “string of pearls” strategy depends on far-flung regional outposts. Some think Cambodia is becoming one.
articles.lead_paragraph: DARA SAKOR, Cambodia — The airstrip stretches like a scar through what was once unspoiled Cambodian jungle.
articles.byline: By Hannah Beech and Adam Dean

articles.headline: Durham Surprises Even Allies With Statement on F.B.I.’s Trump Case
articles.snippet: The federal prosecutor leading a review of the origins of the Russia inquiry has a reputation for keeping his mouth shut. At a sensitive moment, he didn’t.
articles.abstract: The federal prosecutor leading a review of the origins of the Russia inquiry has a reputation for keeping his mouth shut. At a sensitive moment, he didn’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Whether investigating charges of torture by the C.I.A., rolling up an organized crime network or prosecuting crooked government officials, John H. Durham, the veteran federal prosecutor named by Attorney General William P. Barr to investigate the origins of the Russia inquiry, burnished his reputation for impartiality over the years by keeping his mouth closed about his work.

articles.headline: 36 Corvettes, Hidden for Years in a Garage, Will Be Given Away
articles.snippet: The set of ’Vettes, one from each production year between 1953 and 1989, will be part of a sweepstakes drawing next year.
articles.abstract: The set of ’Vettes, one from each production year between 1953 and 1989, will be part of a sweepstakes drawing next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ’56 starred in “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee,” with Jerry Seinfeld and Jimmy Fallon in supporting roles. The ’89 is so ’80s — it has one of those early digital dashboards, with a big-digit speedometer, that were panned by aficionados. The ’53, one of only 100 or so that still exist, has been through a 4,000-hour restoration.

articles.headline: The Unforeseen Dangers of a Device That Curbs Drunken Driving
articles.snippet: Ignition interlock devices are becoming ubiquitous. They can distract drivers and cause crashes.
articles.abstract: Ignition interlock devices are becoming ubiquitous. They can distract drivers and cause crashes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, states have increasingly turned to a powerful tool to stop drunken driving before it starts: miniature breathalyzers, wired into a car’s electronics, that prevent the engine from starting unless the person behind the wheel is sober enough to drive.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Putin’s Russia, Punching Above Its Weight, Keeps Adversaries Off Balance
articles.snippet: Its economy is sputtering and its young people are frustrated, but with America and Europe in tumult, Russia and its leader of two decades are on a roll.
articles.abstract: Its economy is sputtering and its young people are frustrated, but with America and Europe in tumult, Russia and its leader of two decades are on a roll.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Its economy, already smaller than Italy’s, may be sputtering but, two decades after a virtually unknown former K.G.B. spy took power in the Kremlin on Dec. 31, 1999, Russia and its president, Vladimir V. Putin, have just had what could be their best year yet.

articles.headline: Saudi Death Sentences in Khashoggi Killing Fail to Dispel Questions
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia has been accused of shielding Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who foreign experts suspect was behind the killing of Jamal Khashoggi.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia has been accused of shielding Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who foreign experts suspect was behind the killing of Jamal Khashoggi.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia sentenced five men to death and three to prison terms over the killing of the Saudi dissident writer Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul, a ruling widely dismissed as punishing low-level agents while protecting their leaders.

articles.headline: Boeing Fires C.E.O. Dennis Muilenburg
articles.snippet: Boeing has been mired in crisis since the crashes of two of its 737 Max jets killed 346 people.
articles.abstract: Boeing has been mired in crisis since the crashes of two of its 737 Max jets killed 346 people.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing said on Monday that it had fired its chief executive, Dennis A. Muilenburg, who was unable to stabilize the company after two crashes involving its best-selling 737 Max plane killed 346 people and set off the worst crisis in the manufacturing giant’s 103-year history.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: Fresh Evidence in Hand, Schumer Demands More Emails and Documents
articles.snippet: Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, laid out a long list of records Democrats would like to see as the House pressed for testimony from a former White House counsel.
articles.abstract: Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, laid out a long list of records Democrats would like to see as the House pressed for testimony from a former White House counsel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer said on Monday that newly released emails showing that military aid to Ukraine was suspended 90 minutes after President Trump demanded “a favor” from Ukraine’s president were “explosive.” They strengthened, he said, Democratic demands for far more internal administration documents ahead of Mr. Trump’s impeachment trial.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Catie Edmondson
